title: Story of the Year
text:

'''Story of the Year''' is an American [[Rock music|rock]] band formed in [[St. Louis]], Missouri,<ref name=AllMusic>[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p578630|pure_url=yes}} Story of the Year at Allmusic.com] Accessed May 17, 2007.</ref> in 1995 under the name 67 North.<ref name="New Wave of American Heavy Metal" /> The band eventually changed their name to Big Blue Monkey in 1998, and then subsequently changed it again to Story of the Year in 2002, after the release of their EP titled ''Story of the Year'' on the indie label Criterion Records. At the time, they claimed they discovered that a [[blues]] group named Big Blue Monkey had already existed. Later, on their podcast "Page Avenue Crew", they clarified that they just didn't care for the name and made up the excuse of another band having the same name.

It would not be until three years after forming that Story of the Year saw its first piece of commercial success in its major label debut, ''[[Page Avenue]]'', containing the popular singles "[[Until the Day I Die]]" and "[[Anthem of Our Dying Day]]". A second album, ''[[In the Wake of Determination]]'', followed in 2005, but did not achieve the commercial success of its predecessor. The band released their third album, ''[[The Black Swan (Story of the Year album)|The Black Swan]]'', on April 22, 2008, which was their first release on [[Epitaph Records]], followed by 2010's ''[[The Constant (Story of the Year album)|The Constant]]''.

On August 11, 2017, Story of the Year teased a 90-second clip of a new song off their crowd-funded fifth studio album. The pledge campaign began in November 2016 and was completely funded in less than 3 days. The band used high-profile producer [[Aaron Sprinkle]] and mixers [[Tom Lord-Alge|Tom Lord Alge]] & J Hall to complete their fifth studio album. They confirmed via the pledge site that the new album will be titled ''[[Wolves (Story of the Year album)|Wolves]]'', which was released on [[PledgeMusic]] on December 1, 2017. The album's wide release was on December 8, 2017. On February 2, 2019, Story of the Year held their annual hometown show at the Pageant in St. Louis, Missouri to promote ''Wolves''.

==History==
===67 North & Big Blue Monkey (1995–2002)===
The band were formed in 1995 under the name "67 North" by guitarist Ryan Phillips of the bands Means Well and Locash, drummer Dan Marsala, vocalist John Taylor and bassist Perry West. They changed their name to "Big Blue Monkey" in 1998 before releasing the first EP ''Three Days Broken'' that same year. In 1999, they released another EP called ''Truth in Separation'', their last under the line-up. In 2000, West and Taylor would both depart from the group, leading to Marsala moving to vocal duties, and the recruitment of Means Well drummer Josh Wills as well as the members' long time friend Adam Russell on bass duties, despite him never having played bass prior (previously a guitarist prior to joining the band). It was at this point that the band relocated to [[Orange County, California]], where the final Big Blue Monkey EP was released in 2002 titled ''Story of the Year'', which they would then change their name to later that year.<ref name="New Wave of American Heavy Metal" />

===''Page Avenue'' (2002–2004)===
{{Main|Page Avenue}}

After spending many years as a local band with different line-ups, recording three EPs and multiple demos, Story of the Year signed a deal with [[Maverick (company)|Maverick Records]] in 2002, then recorded and released their first album, ''[[Page Avenue]]'', in September 2003. The first single from that album was "Until The Day I Die". It first received radio airplay around July–August 2003 on stations like [[KPNT]]. The second single, "Anthem of Our Dying Day", featured a music video directed by [[Joe Hahn]] of [[Linkin Park]]. Pushed by the success of both singles, ''Page Avenue'' was a success and was certified Gold by the RIAA in 2004,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Gold & Platinum |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/ |access-date=2022-03-20 |website=RIAA |language=en-US}}</ref> and went on to sell 846,000 copies in the US by 2007.<ref name=":1" />

''[[MTV News]]'' reported on their website that during a radio show in May 2004, the band members of Story of the Year got into a fight with the roadies of [[alternative metal|metal]] band [[Godsmack]].<ref>[http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1488110/20040602/story_of_the_year.jhtml?headlines=true Story of the Year Say Godsmack's Crew Kicked Their Asses.] ''MTV News'', June 2, 2004 Accessed February 6, 2007</ref> Pictures of the band members' bruised faces were posted on their homepage. The members of Godsmack were not involved in the fight.

''[[Live in the Lou/Bassassins]]'' (a CD/DVD combo of live performances and touring video) was released on May 10, 2005. It was [[RIAA certification|certified Gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] in late 2005, indicating shipment of over 50,000 units as it is [[Recording Industry Association of America#Video longform certification|video longform]] format.<ref name="riaa">[https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH Gold and Platinum Database Search] Type in "Story of the Year"</ref>

===''In the Wake of Determination '' (2004–2006)===
{{Main|In the Wake of Determination}}

After the ''Page Avenue'' tour ended in late 2004, Story of the Year returned to the studio with producer [[Steve Evetts]] in 2005, to record their second studio album. ''[[In the Wake of Determination]]'', released on October 11, 2005, is much heavier sounding than the previous album. As of October 2007, the album had sold 180,000 units<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Harding |first=Cortney |date=2007-10-29 |title=Story Of The Year Inks With Epitaph |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/story-of-the-year-inks-with-epitaph-1047583/ |access-date=2022-03-20 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> and failed to achieve the same success that the band's two previous releases had.  Although not as successful as its predecessor, the album debuted at No. 19 on the ''Billboard'' 200.

===''The Black Swan'' (2007–2009)===
{{Main|The Black Swan (Story of the Year album)}}

Story of the Year released ''[[The Black Swan (Story of the Year album)|The Black Swan]]'' in 2008. For the album, they brought back producer [[John Feldmann]] and  Elvis Baskette. The album received praise from music critics and achieved decent commercial success, more so than the previous album. The success was led by the first single off album, "Wake Up".

For the recording of ''The Black Swan'', Story of the Year decided to end their five-year relationship with Maverick and signed with [[Epitaph Records]].<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://www.epitaph.com/news/news/2976 |title=Epitaph Records: Epitaph Signs Alt/Rock Heavyweights Story Of The Year |date=October 29, 2007 |publisher=Epitaph.com |access-date=2011-10-31}}</ref>

Story of the Year played on 2008's Taste of Chaos International tour with [[Atreyu]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.kerrang.com/2008/07/atreyu_to_headline_taste_of_ch.html |title=Kerrang! Atreyu to headline Taste Of Chaos 2008 |publisher=.kerrang.com |access-date=2011-10-31 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505194111/http://www2.kerrang.com/2008/07/atreyu_to_headline_taste_of_ch.html |archive-date=May 5, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

===''The Constant'' (2009–2010)===
{{Main|The Constant (Story of the Year album)}}

In May 2009, Story of the Year began work on another album.<ref name=nextalbum>{{cite web|url=http://www.punknews.org/article/33642|title=Story of the Year begin writing next album|last=Punknews.org|website=www.punknews.org|access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref> On December 31, the band released "I'm Alive" to radio airplay.

''[[The Constant (Story of the Year album)|The Constant]]'', was released on February 16, 2010, through Epitaph Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1428472 |title=Story Of The Year Present The Constant - News Article |publisher=AbsolutePunk.net |date=February 16, 2010 |access-date=2011-10-31}}</ref> The Deluxe Edition, available on iTunes, has two bonus tracks, "Your Unsung Friend" and "Tonight We Fall."

Story of the Year recorded a cover of Waterproof Blonde's song "Just Close Your Eyes" for the [[WWE]] [[wrestling]] star [[Christian Cage]]. Their cover version was included in [[WWE Music Group|WWE Music]] album [[WWE The Music: A New Day, Vol. 10|A New Day, Vol. 10]] that was released on January 28, 2010.

===Side-projects and hiatus (2011–2013)===
{{Main|Destroy Rebuild Until God Shows|Greek Fire (band)}}

Bassist [[Adam Russell (musician)|Adam Russell]] was announced to be the bassist of [[post-hardcore]] band [[Destroy Rebuild Until God Shows]], along with [[Craig Owens (vocalist)|Craig Owens]] (lead vocalist, [[Chiodos]]), [[Matt Good]] (guitarist, [[From First to Last]]), [[Nick Martin (musician)|Nick Martin]] (guitarist, [[Underminded]]), and Aaron Stern (drummer, [[Matchbook Romance]]).<ref>{{cite web|last=Ilvonen|first=Keagan|title=D.R.U.G.S Announce Bass Player|url=http://absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1947162&page=2|publisher=[[AbsolutePunk]]|access-date=October 5, 2010|date=October 5, 2010}}</ref> Russell left Destroy Rebuild Until God Shows in 2012.

Singer Dan Marsala formed a fun, [[Comedy rock|comedy punk rock]] side-project in 2009 named The Fuck Off And Dies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.punknews.org/article/36015/story-of-the-year-vocalist-launches-pop-punk-side-project|title=Story Of The Year vocalist launches pop-punk side project|publisher=Punknews.org|author=Paul, Aubin|date=November 16, 2009|access-date=October 12, 2022}}</ref> The band has gone on to release two full-length albums, ''Songs In The Key Of Fuck'' (2011) and ''Dear Liver'' (2015).

Guitarists Ryan Phillips and Philip Sneed continued to pursue their side project, [[Greek Fire (band)|Greek Fire]]. They have released a debut EP and two independent albums, ''Deus Ex Machina'' and ''Lost/Found''.

Bassist Adam Russell and guitarist Ryan Phillips set out to make a movie about rise and fall of the music industry and where it stands today called "Who Killed (Or Saved!) The Music Industry". Funded by [[Kickstarter]], they were filming in 2013.

On February 4, 2011, at The Pageant in their hometown of St. Louis, the band performed their first album, ''Page Avenue'', in its entirety, as well as other fan favorites. They posted that this was a "thank you" show to all their dedicated fans for 10 years together. [[City Spud]], of the St. Louis rap group [[St. Lunatics]], made a guest appearance during the show.

===Reunion, ''Page Avenue'' 10th anniversary tour (2013–2014)===
On March 8, 2013, the band announced they reunited for a world tour to celebrate the 10th anniversary of their debut album ''[[Page Avenue]]''. It was also stated that the band has re-recorded ''Page Avenue,'' entitled ''Page Avenue: 10 Years and Counting'' with release date on October 8, 2013.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=StoryoftheYear|author=Story of the Year|number=380483163702583296|date=19 September 2013|title=Have you seen the preview video for "Page Ave: Ten Years and Counting"? It comes out on Oct. 8th. Check it...}}</ref> Originally they planned it to be a full acoustic version of the album, but after the collaboration with [[City Spud]] during their concert in 2011 they decided to re-record the album with a different feel to each song rather than just acoustic versions.<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/storyoftheyear/posts/10151300295336485 So...it's been a while, huh? After... - Story of the Year]. Facebook. Retrieved on 2013-08-25.</ref>

===''Wolves'' and lineup changes (2014–2019)===
{{Main|Wolves (Story of the Year album)}}
On September 30, 2014, the band announced on their Facebook page that bass player Adam Russell left the band. The band also said they were writing a fifth album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/story_of_the_year_part_ways_with_bassist_post_letter_to_fans_on_their_futur|title=Story Of The Year part ways with bassist, post letter to fans on their future - News - Alternative Press|website=Alternative Press|date=September 30, 2014|access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref> On November 7, 2016 the band announced via their [[PledgeMusic]] page that they would be releasing a new album sometime in 2017 entitled ''[[Wolves (Story of the Year album)|Wolves]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pledgemusic.com/storyoftheyear|title=Story of the Year: WOLVES|website=PledgeMusic|access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref>  On October 25, 2017, via their Facebook page, the band confirmed the [[PledgeMusic]] exclusive release date of ''Wolves'' on December 1, with the album's wide release taking place on December 8.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/storyoftheyear/|title=Story of the Year|website=www.facebook.com|access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref> According to Wall of Sound,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wallofsoundau.com/2017/12/01/story-of-the-year-wolves-album-review/|title=Story of the Year - Wolves (Album Review)|last=Brown|first=Paul|date=2017-12-01|website=Wall of Sound}}</ref> the album has hints of the band's earlier work scattered throughout and a vintage feel, akin to that of [[Stranger Things]].

In March 2018, Philip Sneed announced his departure from the band citing he was let go via management, and not long after, the band announced the return of Adam Russell.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wallofsoundau.com/2018/03/28/philip-sneed-ousted-from-story-of-the-year-ahead-of-australian-tour/|title=Phillip Sneed ousted from Story of the Year|last=Brown|first=Paul|date=March 28, 2018|website=Wall of Sound}}</ref>

===''Tear Me to Pieces'' (2020–present)===

Beginning in October 2020, during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], Story of the Year performed their first three albums in three individual livestreams under the title Ghost Signal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rockcellarmagazine.com/story-of-the-year-live-stream-series-ghost-signal-page-avenue/|title=Punk/Rock Band Story of the Year Playing First Three Albums in Full in New ‘Ghost Signal’ Live Stream Series|date=September 23, 2020|website=Rock Cellar Magazine}}</ref>

In March 2021, ''Page Avenue'' was certified Platinum by the RIAA.<ref name=":0" />

In January 2022 it was announced that Story of the Year would join the [[When_We_Were_Young_(festival)|When We Were Young]] festival among over 60 other emo bands including [[My Chemical Romance]] and [[Paramore]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.altpress.com/when-we-were-young-festival-2022/|title=When We Were Young festival features stacked lineup of Paramore, My Chemical Romance, many more|last=Linzinmeir|first=Taylor|date=January 18, 2022|website=Alternative Press}}</ref> The band released their new single ''Real Life'' on August 24, alongside the announcement they'd signed with [[SharpTone Records]] and a new set of tour dates alongside [[Hawthorne Heights]] and [[Escape the Fate]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Story-of-the-Year-Return-With-New-Single-Real-Life-20220824|title=Story of the Year Return With New Single 'Real Life'|last=Major|first=Michael|date=August 24, 2022|website=Broadway World}}</ref> In October it was announced that Story of the Year's sixth album would be called ''Tear Me to Pieces'', with a new music video for the title track.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blabbermouth.net/news/story-of-the-year-announces-tear-me-to-pieces-album-shares-video-for-title-track|title=STORY OF THE YEAR Announces 'Tear Me to Pieces' Album, Shares Video For Title Track|date=October 12, 2022|website=Blabbermouth}}</ref>

==Musical style and influences==
Story of the Year has been categorized under several genres, especially [[emo]],<ref name=Godsmack/> [[screamo]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thenortherner.com/news/2005/11/09/screamo-band-back-in-action/ |title=Screamo band 'back in action' |work=[[The Northerner (student newspaper)|The Northerner]] |last=Chalfant |first=Dan |date=November 9, 2005 |access-date=March 19, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=New Wave of american Heavy Metal |last=Sharpe-Young |first=Garry |year=2005 |publisher=Zonda Books Limited |isbn= 9780958268400 |page=291}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.altpress.com/features/10_bands_who_will_influence_the_inevitable_pop_screamo_revival_of_2017/ |title=10 Bands Who Will Influence The Inevitable Pop-Screamo Revival Of 2017 |work=[[Alternative Press (magazine)|Alternative Press]] |last=Crane |first=Matt |access-date=March 19, 2020 |date=January 24, 2014}}</ref> [[post-hardcore]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://loudwire.com/american-ninja-warrior-ryan-phillips-story-of-the-year-guitarist/ |title=This Post-Hardcore Guitarist Competed on 'American Ninja Warrior' |work=[[Loudwire]] |last1=Childers |first1=Chad |last2=Trapp |first2=Philip |date=June 25, 2019 |access-date=March 19, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://thesuffolkjournal.com/1662/ac/music/story-of-the-year-back-with-constant-release/ |title=Story of the Year back with 'Constant' release |work=[[The Suffolk Journal]] |last=Maceli |first=Ashley |date=February 24, 2010 |access-date=March 19, 2020}}</ref> and [[Pop-punk|pop punk]].<ref name=SFWeekly>{{cite web |url=https://www.sfweekly.com/music/special-delivery-2/ |title=Special Delivery |work=[[SF Weekly]] |last=Zaleski |first=Annie |date=September 29, 2004 |access-date=March 19, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://drownedinsound.com/news/9787-story-of-the-year-get-godsmack-ed |title=Story Of The Year Get Godsmack'ed! |publisher=[[Drowned in Sound]] |last=Weston |first=Colin |date=June 17, 2004 |access-date=March 19, 2020}}</ref><ref name=Godsmack>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/godsmack-vs-story-of-the-year-indiana-concert-ends-in-savage-beating/ |title=GODSMACK Vs. STORY OF THE YEAR: Indiana Concert Ends In Savage Beating |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |date=2004-06-01 |access-date=2018-01-18}}</ref> [[AllMusic]] describe the band as "emo [[punk rock|punk]]" and "[[emo]]-inflected [[post-grunge]]"<ref name=AllMusic/> and the band has also been labeled as [[alternative rock]]<ref name=axs>{{cite web |url=https://www.axs.com/story-of-the-year-brought-post-hardcore-alternative-rock-into-the-main-41401 |title= Story of the Year brought post-hardcore alternative rock into the mainstream  |publisher=[[AXS (company)|AXS]] |access-date=March 19, 2020}}</ref> and [[melodic hardcore]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Story of the Year – Wolves (Album Review)|date=December 2017|url=https://wallofsoundau.com/2017/12/01/story-of-the-year-wolves-album-review/|access-date=2018-02-07}}</ref> Story of the Year's early material as Big Blue Monkey is considered [[nu metal]].{{sfn|Sharpe-Young|2005|p=291}}

The band's influences include [[Skid Row (American band)|Skid Row]], [[Guns N' Roses]], [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]], [[Pearl Jam]], [[NOFX]], [[Pennywise (band)|Pennywise]], [[Sick of It All]], and [[H2O (American band)|H<sub>2</sub>O]].<ref name=SFWeekly/>

* Adam Russell – bass guitar, vocals (2000–2014; 2018–present)
* Josh Wills – drums, percussion (2000–present)
